questions.text: Which among the following has been marked with the correct types of joints?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C.

1- Intervertebral joint- Secondary cartilaginous joint

2- Suture- Fibrous joint

3- Knee joint- Synovial joint

Structurally, joints are classified as fibrous joints, cartilaginous joints, and synovial joints. 

Structural classification of joints
Type  Subtypes
Fibrous joints
  • Sutures
  • Syndesmosis
  • Gomphosis
Cartilaginous joints
  • Primary cartilaginous (synchondrosis)
  • Secondary cartilaginous (symphysis)
Synovial joints
  • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
  • Sellar or saddle joints
  • Condylar or bicondylar joints
  • Ellipsoid joints
  • Hinge joints
  • Pivot or trochoid joints
  • Plane joints

 

The types of fibrous joints- sutures (a), syndesmosis (b), and gomphosis (c) are shown in the image below:

 

Types of cartilaginous joints:

  • Primary cartilaginous joint: The bones are united by a plate of hyaline cartilage, making the joint immovable. They are temporary joints because the cartilaginous plate gets replaced by bone. Examples are: 
    • The joint between epiphysis and diaphysis of a growing long bone
    • Spheno-occipital joint
    • First chondrosternal joint
    • Costochondral joints
  • Secondary cartilaginous joints: A thin layer of hyaline cartilage covers the articular surfaces, which are united by a fibrocartilaginous disc. These joints are permanent. Examples are :
    • Symphysis pubis
    • Manubriosternal joint
    • Intervertebral joints between the vertebral bodies

Primary (a) and secondary (b) cartilaginous joints are shown below.

 

The articular surfaces of synovial joints are covered with hyaline cartilage and are lubricated with synovial fluid. They are the most mobile joints. Types of synovial joints are shown in the image below: 

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: You are monitoring a 45-year-old female patient in the postoperative ward. Her 24-hour urine output is 1.5 mL/min, serum creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL, and urine creatinine is 60 mg/dL. What is the patient's creatinine clearance rate?
questions.solution:
The creatinine clearance in this patient is 90 mL/min.

Creatinine clearance is defined as the volume of plasma from which creatinine is completely removed by the kidney in a given amount of time (usually minutes).

The formula used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) is:

 UCr × V ⁄ PCr  where,

UCr - Urine creatinine (mg/dL)

PCr - Serum creatinine (mg/dL)

V - Urine volume (mL/min)

Note: The creatinine clearance is usually expressed in mL/min; hence, the preferred unit of urine volume is mL/min, which is calculated based on the 24-hour urine volume. While calculating, ensure that both the urine creatinine and serum creatinine have the same units (either mg/dL or mg/mL).

In the given question,

UCr = 60 mg/dL

PCr = 1.0 mg/dL

V  = 1.5 mL/min

Substituting the values given in the question, we get:

Creatinine clearance =  UCr × V ⁄ PCr ,

= (60 x 1.5)/1

= 60 x 1.5

= 90 mL/min

Creatinine is a by-product of muscle metabolism and is cleared from the body fluids almost entirely by glomerular filtration. Therefore, the clearance of creatinine is used to assess GFR.

Related Pearl: Formulae in renal physiology

Term

Equation

Clearance rate

Us ×V / Ps

 

Glomerular filtration rate

Uinulin × V / Pinulin

 

Clearance ratio

Cs/Cinulin

Effective renal plasma flow

ERPF=CPAH=UPAH ×V / PPAH

 

 

Renal blood flow

RPF / (1− Hematocrit)

Excretion rate

Us ×V

 

Reabsorption rate

=Filtered load −Excretion rate

=(GFR×Ps)−(Us ×V)

Secretion rate

Excretion rate−Filtered load

Cs - clearance rate of substance “s”

EPAH  - PAH extraction ratio

ERPF - effective renal plasma flow

GFR - glomerular filtration rate

P - plasma concentration

PAH - para-aminohippuric acid

PPAH - renal arterial PAH concentration

RBF - renal blood flow

RPF - renal plasma flow

S - a substance

U - urine concentration

V - urine flow rate

VPAH - renal venous PAH concentration

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child has delayed developmental milestones and intellectual disability, with the following appearance (image A). On further examination, there is an enlarged tongue, cloudy cornea, and hepatomegaly. A radiograph of the hand is shown in image B. A girl born in their family also had similar symptoms and she died at 9 years of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Hurler syndrome. The child is 2 years of age and has coarse facial features like a depressed nasal bridge, thick lips, and an open mouth with protruded tongue. The radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpals and phalanges. These features along with severe developmental delay, cloudy cornea, hepatomegaly, and intellectual disability suggest that the child has Hurler syndrome.

It is a severe type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) I. It is caused due to deficiency of α-L-iduronidase. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides. 

Patients usually present between 6-24 months of age. They have

  • Intellectual disability
  • Skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex- thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged diaphyses of the long bones, macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella
  • Cloudy cornea, glaucoma, retinal degeneration
  • Mixed hearing loss, etc

Other options

Option A- The Scheie syndrome is a milder form of MPS-I (MPS I-S ). The symptoms appear after 5 years of age and the diagnosis is made between 10-20 years. It is characterized by normal intelligence and stature, joint stiffness, aortic valve disease, corneal clouding, and mild dysostosis multiplex. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Option B- Hurler-Scheie syndrome is an intermediate between Hurler syndrome and Scheie syndrome. The onset of symptoms is between 3-8 years of age. They have mild or no intellectual dysfunction. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Option D- Hunter syndrome is a type II MPS. It occurs due to the deficiency of iduronate 2-sulfatase. It shares the same features as type I MPS like coarse facial features, short stature, and dysostosis multiplex. However, there is no corneal clouding. It is the only MPS with X-linked recessive inheritance. So if a baby girl is affected in the family, it is less likely to be Hunter syndrome. All the other MPS are autosomal recessive.

Related Pearl: MPS and Their Respective Enzyme Deficiencies

Disease MPS Enzyme defective GAGs affected Symptoms

coarse facial features,

Heparan sulfate		 Mental retardation
Sanfilippo syndrome A MPS IIIA Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase Heparan sulfate Delay in development
Motor dysfunction
Sanfilippo syndrome B MPS III B α-N-Acetylglucosaminidase Heparan sulfate As MPS III A
Sanfilippo syndrome C MPS III C α-glucosaminide N-acetyltransferase Heparan sulfate As MPS III A  
Sanfilippo syndrome D MPS III D N-acetylglucosamine 6-sulfatase Heparan sulfate As MPS III A  
Morquio syndrome A MPS IV A Galactosamine 6-sulfatase Keratan sulfate 
Chondroitin 6-sulfate 		 Skeletal dysplasia
short stature
Morquio syndrome B MPS IV B β-galactosidase Keratan sulfate As MPS IV A
Maroteaux-lamy syndrome  MPS VI N-acetylgalactosamine 4-sulfatase Dermatan sulfate Curvature of the spine,
Short stature

Cardiac defects
Sly syndrome  MPS VII β-glucuronidase Dermatan sulfate
Heparan sulfate

Chondroitin 6-sulfate

Natowicz syndrome  MPS IX Hyaluronidase Hyaluronic acid Joint Pain
Short stature 

Related Pearl: Diseases due to glycoprotein defect

Diseases Defect Characteristics
I-cell disease Mutation in GNPTA gene leading to a deficiency in enzyme UDP-N-acetylglucoseamine-1-phosphotransferase
  • Coarse facial features
  • Corneal erosion
  • Failure to thrive
  • Hepatomegaly
Leukocyte adhesion deficiency, type II Mutations affecting activity of Golgi-located GDP-fucose transporter 
  • Neutrophil rolling
  • Life-threatening, recurrent bacterial infections
  • Psychomotor and mental retardation
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria Genetic mutation leading to the inability to synthesize the glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor that binds certain surface proteins to cell membranes.
  • Lysis of red cells
  • Abdominal pain
  • Back pain
  • Esophageal spasms
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Fatigue
  • Progressive chronic renal failure
  • Thrombophilia
  • Bone marrow failure
  • Venous thrombosis
  • Aplastic anemia
Ehlers–Danlos syndrome Deficiency or mutation in Lysyl hydroxylase-1  
  • Neonatal kyphoscoliosis
  • Generalized joint laxity
  • Skin fragility
  • Severe muscle hypotonia at birth
Oligosaccharidoses Lack of a specific lysosomal hydrolase for glycoproteins
  • Delay in intellectual and physical development.
  • Seizure
  • Joint stiffness and pain
  • Problems with vision and hearing
  • Anaemia, nose bleeds, and easy bleeding or bruising
  • Swollen abdomen due to enlarged spleen or liver. 
Congenital disorders of glycosylation   Glycosylation of a variety of tissue proteins and/or lipids is deficient or defective
  • Fatal, malfunction of several different organ systems
Familial tumoral calcinosis (FTC) UDP-GalNAc transferase 3
  • Calcium deposits in skin and subcutaneous tissues
  • Unresponsiveness to parathyroid hormone
Walker–Warburg syndrome (WWS) Defective α-dystroglycan
  • Agenesis of corpus callosum
  • Anal atresia
  • Atresia of the external auditory canal
  • Blindness
  • Buphthalmos
  • Cerebellar dysplasia
  • Cleft upper lip
Hereditary erythroblastic multinuclearity with positive acidified serum lysis test (HEMPAS) Defects in alpha–mannosidase II
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis
  • Haemolysis & erythroblast morphological abnormalities
  • Hypoglycosylation of some red blood cell (RBC) membrane proteins

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding necroptosis?

choices.text: Kinases like RIP1 and RIP3 are involved
It causes caspase-independent programmed cell death
Cytokine IL-1 plays an important role in the process
Necroptosis starts by ligation of TNFR1

questions.solution:
The fever-inducing cytokine IL-1 plays an important role in pyroptosis and not necroptosis. 

Necroptosis, also known as programmed necrosis, is programmed cell death without caspase activation. It shares features of both necrosis and apoptosis.

It resembles necrosis because of the following features:

  • loss of ATP
  • swelling of the cell and organelles
  • generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS)
  • release of lysosomal enzymes
  • rupture of the plasma membrane

It is triggered by genetically programmed signal transduction events that lead to cell death. This resembles programmed cell death, which is considered the hallmark of apoptosis. Hence, necroptosis is also called programmed necrosis.

Necroptosis does not result in caspase activation, and hence, it is also called “caspase-independent” programmed cell death (option B). The process starts with the ligation of TNFR1 (option D). Ligation of TNFR1 recruits two kinases called receptor-associated kinases 1 and 3 (RIP1 & RIP3) (option A).

Necroptosis begins similarly to the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis, i.e., by receptor-ligand interaction. The most well-studied is the TNF-TNFR mediated pathway. The pathway is demonstrated below:

Pyroptosis is a process of cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and infected cells. This type of programmed cell death is dependent on caspase 1. Caspases 4 and 5 are also involved and cause the death of infected cells. The pathway involves:

Cells infected by microbes → activation of inflammasome complex → activation of the caspase-1 → generation of biologically active IL-1 → fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment.

questions.text: A 44-year-old HIV patient presents with a non-productive cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates along with a pneumatocele. Microscopic examination of the bronchoalveolar lavage shows the following. What is the special stain used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the staining showing the black-colored stained cysts, resembling the crushed ping pong balls, are suggestive of Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii. The stain used for staining the causative organism is Gomori’s methenamine silver stain.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive. Finding on chest x-ray is either a normal film if the disease is suspected early, or diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

Treatment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and pentamidine isethionate

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages  Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

 Spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis 
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers Malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma 

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms
Masson’s Fontana Melanin and argentaffin Cells
Gomori Methenamine Silver Fungi
Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) Myelin
Phosphotungstic Acid-hematoxylin Cross striations of skeletal muscle, fibrin
Toluidine blue Mast cells
Warthin–Starry Helicobacter pylori, spirochetes
Van Gieson Collagen fibres
Mucicarmine Mucin, Cryptococcus capsule

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with seizures. Her parents said this started 15 minutes back and has been continuous. Initial resuscitative measures are taken, and she is given lorazepam. However, her seizures didn’t subside. Which antiepileptic drug is indicated now?
questions.solution:
This patient with seizures for more than 15 minutes has status epilepticus. The treatment algorithm is shown below. According to this, this patient, who did not respond to lorazepam needs phenytoin.

Note: Status epilepticus is defined as continuous seizures or repetitive seizures with impaired consciousness in the interictal period.

The duration of seizure activity to meet the definition of status epilepticus has traditionally been specified as 15–30 min. However, a more practical definition is to consider status epilepticus as a situation in which the duration of seizures prompts the acute use of anticonvulsant therapy, i.e., more than 5 minutes.

questions.text: A police sub-inspector brings the accused in a rape case to a doctor and requests a medical examination. He believes that examination findings would yield evidence to prove the offense allegedly committed. However, the accused is not cooperative. What is the next course of action by the doctor?

choices.text: Request police officer for a court order
Refuse to carry out medical examination without consent
Wait until the accused gives consent

questions.solution:
The next course of action by the doctor is to perform the medical examination by force. 

Section 53 CrPC deals with the examination of the accused by a doctor using force, in the event that the examination has been requested by a police officer (designation of Sub-Inspector and above). The intention behind such a request must be to procure evidence regarding the offense allegedly committed by the accused [Sec. 53 (1) CrPC]. If the person is accused of rape, a medical examination may be carried out by force (in the event of non-cooperation) by the provisions made by Sec. 53A CrPC.

Whenever the person of a female is examined, the medical examination must be carried out only by, or under the direct supervision of a female doctor [Sec. 53 (2) CrPC].

Such an examination is applicable to the testing of blood, blood stains, semen, swabs, sputum, hair samples, and fingernail clippings. 

Other options:

Consent is mandatory for the examination of a victim in criminal cases. Performing an examination by force or by availing of a court order is not allowed for the examination of a victim.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing?
  1. Brainstem-evoked response audiometry
  2. Otoacoustic emissions
  3. Pure tone audiometry 
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA), otoacoustic emissions (OAE), and tympanometry are objective tests for hearing. 

The objective tests of hearing are:

  • Evoked response audiometry
    • Electrocochleography
    • Auditory brainstem response
  • Otoacoustic emissions
  • Impedance audiometry
    • Tympanometry
    • Acoustic reflex measurements

Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA) or Auditory brainstem response (ABR) is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway. It elicits brainstem responses to auditory stimulation. Click stimuli or tone bursts lead to the generation of electrical potentials which are picked up from surface electrodes on the vertex.

Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) refer to an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea. It can be elicited by a microphone in the external auditory canal and is then analyzed by a computer. They test the function of the cochlea. They are used to test hearing in neonates, and sedated/unconscious patients, and to differentiate cochlear from retro-cochlear hearing loss. 

Tympanometry is a component of impedance audiometry. It is an objective test of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing). Here, the compliance of the tympanic membrane, i.e., how much it moves to the pressure differentials applied from the external ear is measured. This is plotted on a graph, to obtain a tympanogram. 

Note- Pure tone audiometry is a subjective test for hearing as it relies on the patient's responses to pure tone stimuli. Other examples of subjective tests include:

  • Tuning fork tests
  • Speech audiometry

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

 

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a wrist drop, severe colicky abdominal pain, and constipation. His peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is the commonest mode of occupational exposure to the compound responsible?
questions.solution:
The clinical background and the image showing basophilic stippling are suggestive of lead poisoning. Inhalation is the most common route of occupational exposure to lead.

Lead poisoning may occur by:

  • Inhalation of fumes and dust of lead
  • Ingestion via contaminated hands or when small amounts of lead trapped in the upper respiratory tract are swallowed.
  • Absorption through the skin

Painters exposed to lead-based paints usually develop plumbism (lead poisoning). The clinical features of lead poisoning include abdominal colic, constipation, loss of appetite, a blue line on the gums (Burtonian line), basophilic stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist drop, and foot drop. CNS symptoms like insomnia, headache, mental confusion, delirium, may also be seen.

Coproporphyrin levels in urine (CPU) are useful in screening. Measurement of blood and urine lead levels should be done for diagnosis.

Chelation with oral DMSA, calcium EDTA, and dimercaprol are treatment modalities. Correction of iron, calcium, zinc, and calcium deficiencies should be done. Vitamin C is a weak chelating agent.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A patient has recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis. Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60 and visual acuity in the left eye 6/18. The patient showed a partial response to steroids. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of neuromyelitis optica, which is also known as Devic's disease.

It is an aggressive inflammatory demyelinating disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of optic neuritis and myelitis. Attacks of Optic neuritis can be bilateral or unilateral and myelitis can be severe and involve three or more contiguous vertebral segments.

Core clinical characteristics are:

  • Optic neuritis
  • Acute myelitis
  • Area postrema syndrome: episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting
  • Acute brainstem syndrome
  • Symptomatic narcolepsy or acute diencephalic clinical syndrome with NMOSD*-typical diencephalic MRI lesions
  • Symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMOSD*-typical brain lesions

Option A: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is a demyelinating condition most frequently associated with an antecedent infection

Option C: Riddoch syndrome is the ability to consciously perceive the stimulus in a blind field. It is seen when there is a lesion in the occipital lobe.

Option D: Acute fulminant multiple sclerosis is an acute episode of multiple sclerosis, known as Marburg’s variant

*NMOSD stands for neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder.

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below that is used to create a pneumoperitoneum ?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a long, slender laparoscopic instrument is Veress Needle. It is used in direct puncture laparoscopy to produce a pneumoperitoneum.

Direct puncture laparoscopy (closed method):

  1. The abdominal wall is grasped with towel clips or fingers to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures. 
  2. A small incision is made in the umbilicus and the Veress needle is introduced into the abdomen. Two distinct pops can be felt as the needle pierces the abdominal wall fascia and the peritoneum.

The umbilicus is the preferred location for introducing a Vereess needle because the abdominal wall is thin at this location.

Carbon dioxide (CO2) gas is usually used and the maximum pressure is in the range of 14-15 mmHg. But N2O is used if the procedure is done under local anesthesia. Insufflation with N2O is stopped at a pressure of 10 mmHg or when 2L of gas is insufflated.

The Hasson Trocar is used to gain access to the peritoneal cavity and generate pneumoperitoneum by the open direct peritoneal access technique (option C). This is known as the Hasson technique and is done only occasionally. It is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound in such cases.

Other options:

Option B: Salah's needle is a type of reusable bone marrow biopsy needle that has a guard situated 2 cm from the tip and a side screw.

Option D: Von Graefe needle (also known as Graefe's knife) is primarily used in ophthalmic surgery.

questions.text: A 20-year old female patient presented with painless lesions on the vulva as shown in the image below. Which of the following vaccines is not protective against this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition in the image is condyloma acuminata (venereal warts) caused by infection with human papilloma virus 6 or 11. The Cervarix vaccine does not protect against it. Cervarix offers protection against HPV subtypes 16,18, which cause CIN and Ca cervix.

The image shows multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal, as seen in condyloma acuminata. The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. They may be asymptomatic but can also cause discomfort, discharge, or bleeding. Treatment may include ablation, excision, or topical agents such as podophyllin and imiquimod.

The available vaccinations against HPV are summarized below.

Brand name Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil-9
Characteristic and HPV subtypes Bivalent:16,18 Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18 Nonavalent: 6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52,58
Protects against: CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, CA cervix,  Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia, Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia
Dose 0.5ml  0.5ml 0.5ml
Administration 0, 1, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6months, i.m
Administered gender Female and male Female and male Female and male
Ideal Age range: 11-12 years,9-26 years  11-12 years, 9-26 years for both male and female

Females:11-12 years, 9-26 years

Males:11-12 years

9-15 years - FDA approved

Gardasil 9 has received expanded indication, which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and other head and neck cancers caused by HPV types 16,18,31,33,45,52,58.

questions.text: A senior pediatric resident uses Silverman Anderson scoring system to assess respiratory distress in newborns. Which of the following components is given a score of 1?

choices.text: Upper chest movement showing inspiratory lag

questions.solution:
According to Silverman Anderson's score, upper chest movement showing inspiratory lag is given a score of 1. 

Expiratory grunting that is audible without a stethoscope and markedly visible xiphoid retractions are given a score of 2. An absence of nasal flaring would be given a score of 0.

Silverman Anderson's score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates. Components of this scoring system include:

    Score    0      1       2

1. Upper chest retraction

(Chest movement)

 Synchronized Lag on inspiration See-saw

2. Lower chest retraction

(Intercostal retraction)

 None Just visible Marked
3. Xiphoid    retraction None Just visible Marked
4. Nasal flaring None Minimal Marked
5. Grunt Not audible Audible with Stethoscope Audible with naked ear

 

The Silverman Anderson Retraction Score is more suited for preterms, however, the Downes’ Score can be applied to any gestational age and condition. Components of Downes' score are respiratory rate, cyanosis, air entry, grunt, and retractions.

questions.text: A 15-year-old child presents with hair loss. The pattern of hair loss is shown in the image below. The hair pull test is negative in other sites. Physical examination also shows cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows alopecia with multiple black dots which is suggestive of tinea capitis. It has to be treated with oral itraconazole.

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children. Clinical features of tinea capitis are patchy hair loss, scaling, tender lymphadenopathy, and in severe cases, there might be pustules and crusting of the affected area.

The clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

  • Endothrix - a non-inflammatory type in which multiple black dots are present within the areas of alopecia. It is most commonly caused by T. tonsurans and T. violaceum.
  • Ectothrix - a mild inflammatory type in which single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss are seen.
  • Kerion - a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation.
  • Favus - is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles.

Other options - 

Option A and C  - Intralesional glucocorticoid and observation are applicable for alopecia aerata. It presents with patchy hair loss and the hair pull test is positive. Observation is also be applicable for telogen effluvium where again there is diffuse hair thinning and positive hair pull test. Both these conditions do not present with lymphadenopathy.

Option D - Minoxidil is used for the treatment of androgenic alopecia which presents with hair loss on the vertex and central region. Additionally, it is unlikely to present at such a young age or with lymphadenopathy.

Below is an image of endothrix variant - 

Below is an image showing kerion variant

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: The maximum oxygen delivered by a nasal cannula is?
questions.solution:
The maximum oxygen delivered by a nasal cannula is 40%.

The nasal cannula is a low flow variable performance oxygen delivery system that can provide a maximum inspired oxygen concentration of 40% at flow rates greater than 10 L/ min for short periods. It is usually limited to a flow of 5-6 L/min to reduce the discomfort resulting from inadequate humidification and high flow into the nasal cavity. It may also cause drying and crusting of the nasal mucosa.

Oxygen delivery devices can be broadly divided into low flow oxygen devices (eg: nasal cannula, simple face mask, non-rebreathing mask) and high flow oxygen devices (eg: venturi mask).

Oxygen delivery devices Flow rate (liter/min)  Approximate FiO2
Nasal cannula  1-6  0.24-0.44 
Simple face mask  6-10 0.40-0.60
Non-rebreathing mask 10-15 0.90-1.00 
Venturi mask  2-15  0.24-0.60

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about open fractures?
  1. Tibia and phalanges are most commonly involved
  2. Usually no co-existing injuries
  3. Compartment syndrome does not occur in open fractures
  4. Early debridement should be done
questions.solution:
Open fractures are usually associated with multiple other injuries and compartment syndrome can occur as a complication of open fractures.

Open fractures are characterized by a break in the overlying skin and soft tissues. Hence, the fracture fragment is exposed to the external environment. It is usually associated with multiple other injuries.

The most common sites involved in open fractures include 

  • Phalanges (Fingers and toes)
  • Tibial diaphysis
  • Distal radius 
  • Ankle

Open fractures are more prone to develop an infection, as it's exposed to the external environment. The presence of an open fracture does not prevent the development of compartment syndrome.

Major components of management of all open fractures are:

  • Antibiotic prophylaxis - It should be given as early as possible
  • Early debridement of the wound and fracture - This includes the following steps:
    • Excision of the wound margins
    • Extension of the wound if required
    • Delivery of the fracture outside the wound for proper examination
    • Removal of the devitalized tissue
    • Cleansing of the wound to remove all the foreign materials
    • Nerves and tendons are usually left alone, but if the wound is clean, a repair can be considered
  • Wound cover:
    • In Gustilo Type I and II fractures wound cover can be done at the time of debridement (Early wound cover)
    • Delayed wound cover is usually practiced in Type III fractures
  • Fracture stabilization - The method of stabilization depends on the degree of contamination, amount of soft tissue damage, and time from the injury to operation.
    • External fixation is used as a temporary measure if there is a delay in wound cover
    • If definitive wound cover can be achieved at the time of debridement and there is no significant contamination, then an open fracture can be managed as same as a closed injury 

Related Pearl: Gustilo and Anderson classification for open fracture

Gustilo-Anderson's classification for open injuries    
Type Wound Level of contamination Soft tissue injury Bone injury
I <1 cm Clean Minimal Simple, minimal comminution
II >1 cm Moderate Moderate; some muscle damage Moderate comminution
IIIA usually >10 cm High Severe with crushing Usually comminuted; soft tissue coverage of bone possible
IIIB usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery
IIIC usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover; vascular injury requiring repair Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery


Management according to Gustilo-Anderson's classification:

Types Methods of fixation
Grade  I                                A technique that is suitable for closed fracture management i.e, debridement and internal fixation by intramedullary nail and plate  
Grade II, IIIA

Within 6hr same as grade I and after 6hr same as IIIB, IIIC
Grade IIIB, IIIC

Debridement and external fixation

questions.text: Acute onset inattention with disorganized thinking and altered level of consciousness is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Acute onset inattention with disorganized thinking and altered level of consciousness is characteristic of delirium.

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a diagnostic algorithm for delirium. The diagnosis of delirium requires the presence of features 1 and 2 and either feature 3 or 4.

  • Feature 1: Acute onset and fluctuating course
    • Positive responses to the following questions satisfy this feature:
      Is there evidence of an acute change in mental status from the patient’s baseline? Does it fluctuate during the day, or does it increase and decrease in severity?
  • Feature 2: Inattention
    • Positive response to the following question satisfies this feature: Is there difficulty focusing attention, easily distractibility, or difficulty keeping track of what was being said?
  • Feature 3: Disorganized thinking
    • A positive response to the following question satisfies this feature: Was the patient’s thinking disorganized or incoherent. Was there rambling or irrelevant conversation, an unclear or illogical flow of ideas, or unpredictable switching from subject to subject?
  • Feature 4: Altered level of consciousness
    • This feature is satisfied by any answer other than “alert” to the following question: Rate the patient’s level of consciousness: alert (normal), vigilant (hyperalert), lethargic (drowsy, easily aroused), stupor (difficult to arouse), or coma (unarousable)?

The scale may not identify the full spectrum of patients with delirium, but all patients who are acutely confused should be presumed delirious. A course that fluctuates over hours or days and may worsen at night is known as sundowning. It is typically seen in delirium, but is not essential for the diagnosis.

Other screening tools that can aid in identifying patients with delirium are:

  • Nursing Delirium Screening Scale (NuDESC)
  • Organic Brain Syndrome Scale
  • Delirium Rating Scale
  • ICU version of the CAM
  • Delirium Detection Score

Related Pearl: Delirium vs Dementia

Features

Delirium

Dementia
Presentation

Hallmark is impaired consciousness

Loss of memory and intellectual abilities

Commonly seen in 

Children and elderly 

Elderly 

Associated physical findings
  • Acute medical illness 
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Abnormal EEG 
  • Carphologia or floccillation (picking movements at cover-sheets and clothes) 
  • No medical illness
  • Little autonomic dysfunction
  • Normal EEG 

Psychological findings
  • Impaired consciousness
  • Illusion, delusion 
  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) 
  • Normal consciousness
  • Depressed mood 
  • Personality changes in early stages in Pick’s disease 
  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) 

Course
  • Develops quickly
  • Fluctuating course with lucid intervals (waxing and waning) 
  • Insidious-onset
  • Progressive downhill course
 

Etiology
  • CNS disease (E.g: Huntington or Parkinson disease)
  • CNS trauma
  • CNS infection (E.g: Meningitis)
  • Systemic disease (E.g., hepatic, cardiovascular)
  • Substance abuse/withdrawal
  • HIV infection
  • Prescription drug overdose (E.g: atropine) 
  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Vascular disease (15-30% of all dementias)
  • CNS disease (E.g., Huntingtons or Parkinsons disease)
  • CNS infection (HIV, Prion diseases)
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Pick's disease (Frontotemporal dementia) 
 

Treatment:

 

Treat the underlying medical cause

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and NMDA antagonist (memantine)

questions.text:
A 61-year-old hypertensive male patient presents with back pain. He has been smoking for the past 30 years. On physical exam, he has an enlarged pulsatile mass over his abdomen. His CT scan is shown below. Which of the following are indications for elective surgical repair in this patient?
  1. Presence of a pulsatile mass on physical exam
  2. Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm ≥5.5 cm
  3. Expansion <0.5 cm in 1 year
  4. Blood pressure >160/100
  5. Associated with iliac arterial aneurysm
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a smoker with abdominal/back pain, history of hypertension and smoking, physical examination revealing a pulsatile mass, and CT findings showing dilation of the abdominal aorta is indicative of abdominal aortic aneurysm(AAA). The following are indications for elective repair of AAA.

  1. Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm ≥5.5 cm
  2. Rapid expansion >1 cm in 1 year.
  3. AAA associated with peripheral arterial aneurysm (eg, iliac, popliteal) or symptomatic peripheral artery disease (eg, iliac occlusive disease) undergoing revascularization

An abdominal aortic aneurysm is commonly asymptomatic and is picked up on screening. Pain may be present in larger aneurysms and is expected over the abdomen or back. Lower limb ischemia may be present in advanced cases. Physical examination may reveal a pulsatile mass in large aneurysms. A ruptured AAA will present with circulatory collapse and acute pain.

It is diagnosed by ultrasonography, which is the screening modality of choice. CT scan is the gold standard for determining the anatomic eligibility for endovascular repair.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions show "Pop corn calcification"?
  1. Fibroadenoma
  2. Fibrous dysplasia
  3. Duct ectasia
  4. Pulmonary hamartoma
  5. Calcified uterine fibroid
questions.solution:
The calcification in duct ectasia has a broken needle appearance. All the other conditions are associated with pop-corn calcification.

Amorphous calcifications with rings and arcs which resemble popped corn kernels in appearance are known as pop-corn calcification. 

It may be seen in 

  • Chondroid lesions like chondrosarcoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Pulmonary hamartomas
  • Fibroadenoma breast
  • Calcified uterine fibroid
  • Metaphyses and epiphyses of long bones of children with osteogenesis imperfecta.

Image showing popcorn calcification in involuted fibroadenoma of the breast is given below:

Note: 

Duct ectasia is associated with coarse rod and branching calcification due to calcification of the debris within the dilated ducts. This is responsible for the broken-needle appearance.

Image showing broken needle calcification in duct ectasia of the breast is given below-

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following fundoscopic findings according to the respective grades in which they are seen, as per Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy, starting with grade 1.
  1. Macular star
  2. Optic Disc swelling
  3. Retinal arteriolar narrowing 
  4. Arteriovenous nipping
questions.solution:
The correct sequence according Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy is

3. Retinal arteriolar narrowing 

4. Arteriovenous nipping

1. Macular star

2. Optic Disc swelling

Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy:

Grade 1: Presence of mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing. 

Grade 2: Presence of focal arteriolar narrowing and arteriovenous nipping.

  • Copper wiring: Opacified appearance of arteriolar walls.
  • Salus’s sign: Deflection of retinal vein as it crosses the arteriole.
  • Gunn’s sign: Tapering of the retinal vein on either side of the AV crossing.
  • Bonnet’s sign: Banking of the retinal vein distal to the AV crossing.

Grade 3: Grade 2 plus retinal hemorrhages, exudates and macular star.

  • Retinal hemorrhages:
    • Dot-blot hemorrhages: Bleeding in the inner retinal layer
    • Flame shaped hemorrhage: Bleeding is in the superficial retinal layer
  • Retinal exudates:
    • Hard exudates: Lipid deposits in the retina
    • Soft exudates: These are also known as cotton wool spots which appear due to ischemia of the nerve fibers
  • Macular Changes
    • Macular star formation due to deposition of hard exudates around the macula.

Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling. This is a marker of malignant hypertension.
